text: That naughty Mr ⁦⁦⁦@MattChorley⁩: “There has also been a campaign for a set of stamps to be issued with reports of ‘fury’ that Brexit was being overlooked in favour of neglected beavers (a cause close to Boris Johnson’s heart).”
author: TomMcTague

text: Would he resign to stop no deal?
author: TomMcTague

text:
Basic questions we don't know the answer to: 
Will there be a Stormont Lock?
Is new Vienna advice coming?
When will MV3 happen?
Will MPs get vote on Euro election participation?
Does EU have Irish border plan for no-deal?
Can May be forced to apply for long extension?
author: TomMcTague

text: Brexit: What happens next?
author: TomMcTague

text: One euroskeptic on why May's days might *not* be numbered: "Betting against her stubbornness and for cabinet strength has not been a winning strategy thus far."
author: TomMcTague

text: Could May get out ahead by making MPs vote on whether the UK should take part in Euro elections? I’m not convinced there’s a majority. Defeat would effectively impose April 12 deadline, deal or no deal, potentially forcing Labour’s hand to abstain or offer free vote on MV4.
author: TomMcTague

text: Yep.
author: TomMcTague

text: What's the EU plan though?
author: TomMcTague

text: Interesting point. The main stumbling blocks, I think, are a) the link to a perm customs union (partially broken in the exchange of letters) and b) the inability to control what comes next — the ERG worry May will turn them over & Lab worry the ERG will turn May over
author: TomMcTague

text: By the way Daniel, do you know what the EU plan is for the Irish border in the event of no-deal. Or Dublin’s position? They don’t appear to have ever said. Customs checks with continent or with N Ireland?
author: TomMcTague

text: Exactly. For some reason it appears to be being construed as anti-Irish, rather than an obvious statement of Ireland’s diplomatic weight right now.
author: TomMcTague

text: Exactly - this tweet suggests the claim that there might not be a long extension was a bluff (because the only alternative is solidarity with Ireland has gone)
author: TomMcTague

text: No, you’re not getting it. I was saying I found Macron’s claims pre summit extraordinary: I didn’t buy them. Why? Because I don’t think they will screw Ireland if they can help it. (& I don’t understand fixation with “division” - obviously was division but they came to a deal)
author: TomMcTague

text: Don’t really understand your point Daniel. Turns out he didn’t go through with it - UK can have short, medium or long extension depending on what it does. Ireland was not thrown under a bus, as I said I found extraordinary. That was the point of the tweet
author: TomMcTague

text: For the latest — EU summit: Live blog
author: TomMcTague

text: Still extraordinary the UK is outside a room where its fate is being decided
author: TomMcTague

text: I’ll book my Eurostar now then shall I?
author: TomMcTague

text: French speakers: why is it "the Brexit" in French but only "Brexit" in English?
author: TomMcTague

text: Has May flipped? Has she really concluded no-deal is better than a long extension? No-one knows. Here's my go at getting inside her mind
author: TomMcTague

text: "Special place in hell."
author: TomMcTague

text: Sorry Ireland, says Macron. This far and no further. Would be extraordinary if he follows through, though not impossible of course.
author: TomMcTague

text: Quite. It is existential. Hence why the peace process started in the late 1980s only concluded in 1998. Here, we have set a two-year all-or-nothing deadline
author: TomMcTague

text: Everyone has already said it, but this — by @iainmartin1 — really is very good
author: TomMcTague

text: I wouldn't classify dying as a success...
author: TomMcTague

text: If Labour introduced a vote of no confidence on Tuesday, it could be passed Wednesday — and, in theory, a national unity majority could be formed that day, which could revoke/extend article 50 before Friday. Unlikely, but not impossible
author: TomMcTague

text: There is no cross party consensus in Northern Ireland. What the DUP and UUP want, the EU says it cannot give. This is the Colin Powell break-it-own-it theory: once backstop is introduced, what comes next in NI is a joint EU/UK problem because it has been imposed without consensus
author: TomMcTague

text: Agree. How to square with warning yesterday that she would not want to extend as PM though? Just bluff? Or extend as final duty to parliament before resigning?
author: TomMcTague

text: Imagine May calls a snap election next week after losing MV3 — and wins the May 2 election. She then pushes through the withdrawal agreement, opposed by DUP and UUP. Does anyone seriously think that's crisis over? It would just be the start
author: TomMcTague

text: "No EU country wants to be blamed for precipitating a no-deal Brexit that would inflict severe economic damage not just on the UK but also its nearest neighbours, especially Ireland." Why you should take the bellicose EU language with a large pinch of salt
author: TomMcTague

text: What's needed
author: TomMcTague

text: Ireland would be the worst affected member state should a request for an extension be rejected. It would also impose a border, which the backstop is there to avoid. It doesn’t have to request, it’s obvious
author: TomMcTague

text: Varadkar: “I’d certainly rather see an extension than seeing the UK leave without a deal. A long extension creates a complication in relation to the European elections, but that’s a small complication relative to the impact on our economy.”
author: TomMcTague

text: Coveney and Varadkar have said so publicly
author: TomMcTague

text: If there’s no withdrawal agreement, then what? You have been out in front on this one - it’s a border in Ireland right?
author: TomMcTague

text:
The EU has stood shoulder to shoulder with Ireland, we are told.

Ireland has been clear it wants a long extension, both for economic reasons and to protect the border.

Now we’re told France could veto an extension should MPs vote against the deal.

Solidarity gone or a bluff?
author: TomMcTague

text: Things just got more
author: TomMcTague

text: We are nine days away from no-deal, Tusk has just declared. A reminder: the EU has still not said what its plans are for the Irish border.
author: TomMcTague

text: Steve Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, says no Brexit would be bad for British democracy and no-deal bad for the British economy. He tells MPs of the two he would prefer the economic hit of no-deal, despite the added risks to the union
author: TomMcTague

text:
Seems a particularly weak excuse to say the letter came too late. The real reason is the EU doesn’t want to do May’s dirty work, as they see it. 

Brussels’ message: Sort your s*** out and then come back to us.
author: TomMcTague

text: At a private dinner with French officials last year one (anti Brexit) figure warned the UK-France defence relationship could not be quarantined from any Brexit fallout. "You can't say we'll have your Chinooks *and* your bankers, it doesn't work like that." Things could turn nasty
author: TomMcTague

text: If France sees through on this, it's game over. Blocking the UK taking part in Euro elections means it's deal and short extension next week — or no deal on March 29
author: TomMcTague

text: Emergency three-hour debate on May's extension request happening TODAY
author: TomMcTague

text:
.@tobyperkinsmp asks if Brexiteer MPs will need grief counselling if the UK leaves because they'll have nothing left to talk about. Mark Francois: "I'll have no need for grief counselling, but I'll have a whacking great hangover on the morning of the 30th."
Debate at its finest
author: TomMcTague

text:
We're heading for a  week!
EU leaders respond to June 30 extension request
Govt tables amendable motion on way forward Mon
Amendments galore!
Votes in both houses to change exit day
Stormont lock published
Meaningful vote 3
Emergency summit?
Resignation?
author: TomMcTague

text:
May resurrects the “Stormont Lock” in the original Dec 2017 backstop agreement. 

Politico revealed this plan in January: “‘Paragraph 50 needs to go back in,’ said one senior UK official familiar with the prime minister’s thinking.”
author: TomMcTague

text: Commission: Brexit must happen by May 23 or the UK must hold EU election – POLITICO
author: TomMcTague

text:
Resignation warning
Letter should be read alongside May’s words at PMQs. In letter she says she wants a short extension to have another go at getting her deal through, but if this fails a long extension needed. May has just told MPs she won’t apply for long extension
author: TomMcTague

text: MP shouts at the prime minister: “You are a disgrace.”
author: TomMcTague

text: May accuses “this house of contemplating its naval” for too long. She is drowned out by a chorus of “resign!” from the Labour benches. Screams of “shame” and “arrogant.” Things turning nasty
author: TomMcTague

text: Big move from May. She says she is not prepared to see Brexit delayed beyond 30th June. So, it could be Brexit in three months — or a new PM and probably elections shortly after. The shake down has started, finally.
author: TomMcTague

text: Is this sustainable, I ask one Tory MP? “It shouldn't be. But chaos and dysfunction has been normslised... so we can bob along this level for a while yet.”
author: TomMcTague

text: Every time this feels unsustainable — the election, Chequers, Salzburg, MV1, Sharm, MV2 — it sustains itself. Today another example, but who's betting the crisis won't just roll on? The most unremarked aspect of Brexit is how calm meh real-world Britain has remained. Sustainable?
author: TomMcTague

text: Project Optimist.
author: TomMcTague

text:
“Britain would spend the next seven to 10 years trying to work out what the future was like outside the EU and what our relationship would be with it."
— David Cameron, last edition of Independent on Sunday, 20 March 2016
https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/david-cameron-interview-prime-minister-urges-people-to-vote-in-eu-referendum-or-youll-find-were-out-a6941436.html …
author: TomMcTague

text:
Three years ago today*, my interview with David Cameron ran in the last edition of the Independent on Sunday: PM raises fears apathetic voters will hand victory to Brexit.

*three years!
author: TomMcTague

text:
Does short extension *increase* chances of Tory split? By resuscitating no-deal, at least in minds of no-dealers, it reduces incentive for them to vote for May’s deal. Given the numbers in parliament, this makes a softer Brexit *more* likely not less*

*I think, but who knows
author: TomMcTague

text: The gif of our times
author: TomMcTague

text: Based on the conversations I had with people in Brussels yesterday, there was already a hardening in the EU *against* a long extension. I suspect we’re heading for a vote on taking part in the European elections early April. If May wins this, no-deal is dead but v much alive
author: TomMcTague

text: Story, by top colleague @florianeder
author: TomMcTague

text: Chicken Sushi is, er... not a thing
author: TomMcTague

text: This is really very good
author: TomMcTague

text:
“I know you attach great weight to what you think.”
— John Bercow, March 19, 2019
author: TomMcTague

text: I think, though, that if the UK and EU27 agree an X extension on Thursday, that’s it, game over - March 29 is gone. Certainly in international law. Whether that will happen is a different story...
author: TomMcTague

text: Not sure Bercow rules on international law
author: TomMcTague

text: GB promise to stick to NI standards, which will be set by EU, kills the point of Brexit for most Brexiteers. This is *the* question for MPs: are you willing to pay the price of NI divergence for the shiny Brexit prize in the window (without checking to see what’s it’s made of)?
author: TomMcTague

text: Amazing
author: TomMcTague

text: Oof
author: TomMcTague

text: Indeed, but no cliff edge on March 29 - so no immediate pressure to do the deal
author: TomMcTague

text:
Huge 36 hours ahead for May and Brexit:
No deal with the DUP by tonight, no vote tomorrow
No vote tomorrow, risk automatic long extension Thurs
Extension Thurs, no March 29 
No March 29, no cliff edge
No cliff edge, no May, no Brexit or no deal..
author: TomMcTague

text:
“If we were guided only by precedent, manifestly nothing in our procedures would ever change."
— House of Commons Speaker John Bercow, January 9, 2019

(h/t @JulianLyons_WPS)
author: TomMcTague

text: Exactly
author: TomMcTague

text: Increases chances of no-deal now, yes. But increases likelihood of no-Brexit far more substantially. If no MV3 before Thurs, May obliged to ask EU for a delay, which it can grant at stroke of a pen. And Brexit is re-radicalised, to be settled in an election and possible 2nd ref
author: TomMcTague

text: Lab, I think, will have to fall into line behind a "our negotiated deal put to the people with an option to remain." Effectively a fight between second referendum and no-deal in an election. Winner takes all
author: TomMcTague

text: Some close to May have long thought all roads lead to an election. Events conspiring to prove them right. "One of the times I do not like being correct," says one. Seems to many that we're heading for an election, post extension, under a new Tory leader promising no-deal
author: TomMcTague

text: I give you a map of Britain & Ireland from 1646 which helps explain Brexit. English Channel is v important: “The British Ocean.” North Sea, less so: “The German Sea.” There’s not much in Ireland, Scotland is split between the Picts and Scots, Wales is Wales and Europe is abroad
author: TomMcTague

text: The strange tale of the Vienna get-out clause. @SteveBarclay told @Jacob_Rees_Mogg Article 62, which insures against "unforeseen circumstances," was key. Barclay said, for eg, what if the peace process was undermined? Big problem: Barclay just foresaw it
author: TomMcTague

text: Forget holding its nose to vote for the deal, Theresa May needs Westminster to close its eyes to the realities of the backstop — and Brussels to bite its tongue. The Vienna Convention is a blindfold. My latest here https://www.politico.eu/article/uk-prime-minister-theresa-may-turns-to-vienna-for-brexit-help-delay-irish-backstop/ …
author: TomMcTague

text: Not sure this is the line...
author: TomMcTague

text: Part four: What’s that scribbled on the bench? Oh
author: TomMcTague

text: Part three: you notice the bench has one of those plaques in memory of a couple who also liked the spot. Ah, that’s nice, you think
author: TomMcTague

text: Part two: your little one wants to stop for a sit down on the park bench you’re passing. Why not? Nice spot
author: TomMcTague

text: When you’re out for a walk and you turn into Holden Caulfield. Part one: the world is nice, London is pretty
author: TomMcTague

text: I wonder if there are two chances for May to bring back her deal: next week before the European Council and then again between the summit and March 29 just before she formally extends article 50 with an SI (and resigns shortly after)
author: TomMcTague

text: Para 50 guarantees the UK will ensure no new regulatory barriers will develop between NI and GB, “unless... the NI Executive and Assembly agree that distinct arrangements are appropriate for Northern Ireland." May needs a domestic way to enact this pledge. At risk: US FTA
author: TomMcTague
